citeinfo.title: Changes in Anthropogenic Influences on Streams and Rivers: Land Use

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of 24 tables of data representing land use from two sources, one source represents three time steps for the period 2001-2011 (based on National Land Cover Dataset (NLCD)) and one source represents five time steps for the period 1974-2012 (from the NAWQA Wall-to-Wall Anthropogenic Landuse Trends (NWALT) dataset). One set of tables contains data for Hydrologic Unit Code 10 (HUC-10) areas, one set of tables for USEPA Level IV ecoregions, and one set of tables for 2010 U.S. county boundaries. Each table provides data for one data source and one boundary dataset.
descript.purpose: These data are intended to provide a framework in which watershed-specific studies of water quality in streams and rivers may be analyzed. The focus of the data is on anthropogenic changes over time.
descript.supplinf:
Twenty-four comma-separated text files are given here. Each file contains a "uniqid" field, which is the link to the data in other datasets in this product. The files representing HUC-10 areas has 15,458 rows, the files representing Level IV ecoregions has 967 rows, and the files representing U.S. counties has 3,109 rows. There are similarities between the NLCD and the NWALT products however they are not directly comparable. That is, users should use either the NLCD values as a time series, or the NWALT-derived values as a time series, but not mix them. See supportive documentation in references for more information on source data. The NWALT data are derived from Falcone, 2016 ("Enhanced Grazing Potential" version), which is in turn a slight modification of the product in Falcone, 2015. The only difference is that the 2016 product has some pixels which were classified as "Low Use" (class 50) in the original, reclassified as "Grazing Potential" (class 46). They are otherwise identical. All NLCD data are derived from the NLCD 2011 harmonized versions of the NLCD 2001, 2006, 2011 (mrlc.gov) from October 2014. The stated USGS preferred citations for NLCD products are: NLCD 2001 products: Homer and others, 2007. NLCD 2006 products: Fry and others, 2011 NLCD 2011 products: Homer and others, 2015. Citations for the boundaries used are: HUC-10 boundaries: National Resources Conservation Service, 2017; Level IV ecoregion boundaries: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013; 2010 counties: National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013. References: Falcone, J.A., 2015, U.S. conterminous wall-to-wall anthropogenic land use trends (NWALT), 1974-2012. U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 948, 33 p. plus appendices 3-6 as separate files, http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ds948. Falcone, J.A., 2016, Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7CR5RFF. Fry, J., Xian, G., Jin, S., Dewitz, J., Homer, C., Yang, L., Barnes, C., Herold, N., and Wickham, J., 2011, Completion of the 2006 National Land Cover Database for the Conterminous United States, Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, Vol. 77(9):858-864. Homer, C., Dewitz, J., Fry, J., Coan, M., Hossain, N., Larson, C., Herold, N., McKerrow, A., VanDriel, J.N., and Wickham, J., 2007, Completion of the 2001 National Land Cover Database for the Conterminous United States, Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, Vol. 73, No. 4, pp 337-341.
Homer, C.G., Dewitz, J.A., Yang, L., Jin, S., Danielson, P., Xian, G., Coulston, J., Herold, N.D., Wickham, J.D., and Megown, K., 2015, Completion of the 2011 National Land Cover Database for the conterminous United States-Representing a decade of land cover change information. Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing, v. 81, no. 5, p. 345-354. National Historical Geographic Information System, 2013, U.S. geographic summary data and boundary files, 2010: National Historical Geographic Information System, Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS), county boundaries, accessed February 1, 2013 at: https://www.nhgis.org/. National Resources Conservation Service, 2017, Watershed boundary dataset (WBD): National Resources Conservation Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, available at https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/technical/nra/geo/, accessed January 9, 2018 from https://nrcs.app.box.com/v/huc/folder/39640323180. Price, C. V., Nakagaki, Naomi, and Hitt, K. J., 2012, National Water-Quality Assessment (NAWQA) Area-Characterization Toolbox, Release 2.0, U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2010-1268. http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2010/1268. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 2013, Level IV ecoregions of the conterminous United States: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development â€“ National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory, accessed November 17, 2017 at: https://www.epa.gov/eco-research/level-iii-and-iv-ecoregions-continental-united-states.

County boundaries used in data calculations.

citeinfo.title: Level III and IV ecoregions of the continental United States

srcinfo.srccontr: Level IV ecoregion boundaries used in data calculations.
NLCD 2001 dataset from which land cover was derived
NLCD 2006 dataset from which land cover was derived

citeinfo.title: Mapping enhanced grazing potential based on the NAWQA Wall-to-wall Anthropogenic Land-use Trends (NWALT) product, 1974-2012

srcinfo.srccontr: Source dataset from which land use for 1974-2012 were derived

procstep.procdesc: (1) Source data from the NLCD were downloaded (https://www.mrlc.gov/) and converted to grid format in March 2015. The source data for the NLCD are the October 2014 normalized version of data, where all years have been adjusted to agree with one another.
(2) Source data from NWALT were based on Falcone (2016).
(5) HUC-10, Eco-IV, and county land use category percentages were calculated using the USGS NAWQA Area-Characterization Toolbox (Price and others, 2012).

enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of comma-separated text files. There are 24 tables: landuse-county-nwalt1974.txt, landuse-county-nwalt1984.txt, landuse-county-nwalt1992.txt, landuse-county-nwalt2002.txt, landuse-county-nwalt2012.txt, landuse-county-nlcd2001.txt, landuse-county-nlcd2006.txt, landuse-county-nlcd2011.txt, landuse-eco4-nwalt1974.txt, landuse-eco4-nwalt1984.txt, landuse-eco4-nwalt1992.txt, landuse-eco4-nwalt2002.txt, landuse-eco4-nwalt2012.txt, landuse-eco4-nlcd2001.txt, landuse-eco4-nlcd2006.txt, landuse-eco4-nlcd2011.txt, landuse-huc10-nwalt1974.txt, landuse-huc10-nwalt1984.txt, landuse-huc10-nwalt1992.txt, landuse-huc10-nwalt2002.txt, landuse-huc10-nwalt2012.txt, landuse-huc10-nlcd2001.txt, landuse-huc10-nlcd2006.txt, landuse-huc10-nlcd2011.txt

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number
attr.attrdefs: Unique integer ID used for internal processing and for linking data from other tables for HUC-10, Eco-IV, and county data.

attrdomv.udom: Unique identifier for either "huc10"s, "county"s, or "eco4"s, where YYYY represents one of those three terms

attr.attrdef: Percent watershed Open Water (class 11), for 2001, 2006, or 2011 (year represented by XX). Scale represented by YYYY, one of "huc10", "county", or "eco4"
